headline.seo: Even as Obesity Concerns Rise, Physical Education Is Sidelined
headline.print_headline: Gym Class Finds Itself On Sideline
headline.main: Despite Obesity Concerns, Gym Classes Are Cut

docs.abstract: Biennial survey by Centers for Disease Control and Prevention finds that many American high school students are offered little or no physical education; in New York City, where the Bloomberg administration has received high marks from public heath advocates for its anti-obesity policies, 20.5 percent of public school students reported that they had no physical education classes, compared with 14.4 percent a decade earlier.
docs.lead_paragraph: Many American students are being offered little or no physical education as schools blame budget cuts.
docs.snippet: Many American students are being offered little or no physical education as schools blame budget cuts.

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
keywords.name: organizations

headline.seo: Q. and A. - Are High-Protein, Low-Carb Diets Effective?
headline.print_headline: In Dieting, Magic Isn’t A Substitute For Science
headline.main: In Dieting, Magic Isn’t a Substitute for Science

docs.abstract: Interview with prominent obesity researcher Dr Jules Hirsch on the findings of a recent, widely-read study in The Journal of the American Medical Association suggesting that people on a high-fat, high-protein diet burn more calories than those eating more carbohydrates.
docs.lead_paragraph: A much-publicized study suggesting that a high-protein diet is better for weight loss is just an illusion, as are other diets, one expert says.
docs.snippet: A much-publicized study suggesting that a high-protein diet is better for weight loss is just an illusion, as are other diets, one expert says.

keywords.value: Journal of the American Medical Assn
keywords.name: organizations

headline.main: Personal Health: Relief Tips for Joints Besieged by Arthritis

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column recommends several alternatives to surgery for older patients suffering from pain caused by osteoarthritis or reduced function in joints like knees and hips. Drawing (M)/
docs.lead_paragraph: If you live long enough - that is, beyond 50 or 60 - chances are one or more of your joints, probably your knees or hips, will become arthritic. And if pain or stiffness begin to seriously limit your ability to enjoy life and perform routine tasks, chances are you'll consider replacing the troublesome joint. ''People with osteoarthritis are relying more and more heavily on surgery,'' Dr. David T. Felson, a rheumatologist and epidemiologist at Boston University School of Medicine, told me. ''The rate of knee replacement is just skyrocketing, out of proportion to increases in arthritic changes seen on X-rays, and replacement surgery is contributing greatly to the rising costs of Medicare.''
docs.snippet: If you live long enough - that is, beyond 50 or 60 - chances are one or more of your joints, probably your knees or hips, will become arthritic. And if pain or stiffness begin to seriously limit your ability to enjoy life and perform routine tasks,...

headline.print_headline: Personal Health: Relief Tips for Joints Besieged by Arthritis
headline.main: Relief for Joints Besieged by Arthritis

docs.abstract: People with osteoarthritis are increasingly choosing knee or hip replacement, but there are many potential remedies short of surgery to ease pain and to preserve - and perhaps restore - joint function.
docs.snippet: People with osteoarthritis are increasingly choosing knee or hip replacement, but there are many potential remedies short of surgery to ease pain and to preserve - and perhaps restore - joint function.

headline.print_headline: The Debate Over the Causes of Obesity
headline.main: The Debate Over the Causes of Obesity

docs.lead_paragraph: Readers respond to a Sunday Review article, “What Really Makes Us Fat.”
docs.snippet: Readers respond to a Sunday Review article, “What Really Makes Us Fat.”

byline.original: By ELIZABETH W. DUNN and MICHAEL NORTON

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Profs Elizabeth Dunn and Michael Norton describes their research into the relationship between money and happiness; observes that their research has shown that those who spend more of their money on others tend to be happier than those who buy things for themselves.
docs.lead_paragraph: Once you have about $75,000 a year, earning more doesn’t really help. The secret to consistent pleasure? Buying for others.
docs.snippet: Once you have about $75,000 a year, earning more doesn’t really help. The secret to consistent pleasure? Buying for others.
